Cantor

Contents

  • Transfinitude
    • The Curse of the Rebellious Set
    • More Parts Than Wholes

Cantor#

Je le vois, mais je ne le crois pas!

—Correspondence with Richard Dedekind, Georg Cantor, 1877

Transfinitude#

The Curse of the Rebellious Set#

Definition: The Rebellious Set

Let \(A\) be any set and let \(P(A)\) be it’s power set. Assume \(f: A \to P(A)\). The Rebellious Set, denoted R, is defined as the set which satisfies this formula,

\[R = \{ x \in A \, \mid \, x \notin f(x) \}\]

Theorem \(f: A \to P(A) \leftrightarrow \lvert R \rvert \geq 1\)

Let \(P(A)\) be the power set of \(A\) (the set of all subsets of \(A\)). Suppose there exists a bijection \(f: A -> P(A)\). This means every element in \(A\) is paired with a unique subset of \(A\), and vice versa.

If \(A = \emptyset\), then its power set \(P(A)\) contains one element, the empty set itself, \(P(A) = {∅}\). In this case, there’s no bijection between \(A\) and \(P(A)\), and the theorem holds trivially.

If \(A \neq \emptyset\), it must contain at least one element. Let a be this element. Consider the subset of \(A`\) that contains only this element, \(\{a\}\). Since f is assumed to be a bijection, there must be some element \(y \in A\) such that \(f(y) = \{a\}\).

If \(y = a\), then, \(a \in f(a)\), which contradicts the definition of \(B\) (that is, the elements in \(B\) are not in the set they are mapped to).

If \(y \neq a\), then \(y \notin f(y)\), which means y should be in \(B\) according to its definition. Since y exists, \(B\) is not empty. ∎

More Parts Than Wholes#

Theorem \(\forall A: \lvert P(A) \rvert > \lvert A \rvert\)

For the sake of contradiction, suppose there exists a bijection (a one-to-one correspondence) \(f: A \to P(A)\). This means every element in \(A\) is paired with a unique subset of \(A\), and vice versa.

Consider the rebellious set,

\[R = \{ x \in A \, \mid \, x \notin f(x) \}\]

This set \(R\) contains all elements of \(A\) that are not members of the subset they are mapped to by f. By the previous theorem, this set is non-empty. Since f is a bijection, there must be an element \(r \in A\) such that \(f(r) = R\).

If \(r \in R\), then by the definition of \(R\), \(r ∉ f(r)\). But \(f(r) = R\), so \(r \notin R\), a contradiction.

If \(r \notin R\), then by the definition of \(R\), \(r ∈ f(r)\). But \(f(r) = R\), so \(r \in R\), again a contradiction.

The initial assumption that there exists a bijection between \(A\) and \(P(A)\) must be false.

Therefore,

\[\lvert P(A) \rvert > \lvert A \rvert\]
